item.title: Reshuffle: Boris Johnson fires Gavin Williamson as he rings cabinet changes
item.description: The PM fires Gavin Williamson and replaces the foreign secretary in a day of drama at Westminster.

item.title: UK, US and Australia launch pact to counter China
item.description: The partnership will enable Australia to build nuclear-powered submarines for the first time.

item.title: Simone Biles: 'I blame system that enabled Larry Nassar abuse'
item.description: Four Olympic gymnasts blast the FBI for failing to act on their complaints about the USA team doctor.

item.title: Former IS teenage bride Shamima Begum offers to help fight terror in UK
item.description: The 22-year-old, who left London at 15 to join the Islamic State group, says she could be useful.

item.title: Paris attacks trial: Abdeslam blames France for bombing IS
item.description: Salah Abdeslam shocks his trial, describing the bomb and gun attacks as "nothing personal".

item.title: Afghanistan: Life under Taliban rule one month on
item.description: Secunder Kermani looks at life in northern Afghanistan, four weeks after the militants seized power.

item.title: Prince Andrew case: High Court to notify duke of US civil proceedings
item.description: Virginia Giuffre is suing the prince in New York over allegations of sexual assault.

item.title: Facebook under fire over secret teen research
item.description: It had evidence Instagram was a harmful place for young people - but failed to share its findings.

item.title: Primark claims clothes will now be eco-friendly and affordable
item.description: The chain says its clothes will stay reasonably priced but will be more sustainably sourced.

item.title: Martin Bashir: Police take no action over Diana interview
item.description: Detectives find no evidence of criminal activity associated with the 1995 Panorama programme.

item.title: Covid-19: Pope puzzled about vaccine hesitancy in the Church
item.description: Pope Francis says most people at the Vatican are vaccinated except for a "small group".

item.title: Manchester Arena Inquiry told police failed in response to bombing
item.description: Police "failed" in their response to the Manchester Arena attack in 2017, an inquiry hears.

item.title: Liverpool 3-2 AC Milan: Reds pull off comeback in Champions League epic
item.description: Jordan Henderson's strike gives Liverpool victory in a remarkable Champions League group opener against AC Milan.

item.title: Microsoft's passwordless plans lets users switch to app-based login
item.description: Microsoft says users can delete all passwords from their accounts and use a different login system.

item.title: Liz Truss: Fast tracker who landed prime cabinet role
item.description: The life of the new foreign secretary, from left-wing parents to the top of the Conservative Party.

item.title: Cabinet reshuffle 2021: Who is in Boris Johnson's new cabinet?
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson reshuffles his cabinet for the first time since February 2020. Who's in it now?

item.title: Government reshuffle hires and fires
item.description: The prime minister has fired a string of cabinet ministers in a major cabinet reshuffle.

item.title: Nadine Dorries becomes new culture secretary
item.description: The MP for Mid Bedfordshire and former health minister replaces Oliver Dowden.

item.title: Cabinet reshuffle: Losers, winners and challenges ahead
item.description: Our correspondents look at the legacy of those out of a job and the challenges facing their successors.

item.title: Cabinet reshuffle: Where did it go wrong for Gavin Williamson?
item.description: The reshuffle has seen the removal of an education secretary much criticised during the pandemic.

item.title: Who is Dominic Raab? Karate black-belt who is no stranger to controversy
item.description: The Conservative MP loses his job at the foreign office but becomes deputy PM and justice secretary.

item.title: The Papers: PM 'wields axe' as he 'lays ground for next election'
item.description: Thursday's front pages are dominated by Boris Johnson's major reshuffle of his cabinet.

item.title: Emma Raducanu 'hungry' to improve after US Open win - but not sure on Indian Wells
item.description: Britain's Emma Raducanu says she is "hungry" to improve after her US Open win but wants a few days' rest first.

item.title: Louise Minchin: BBC Breakfast bids presenter goodbye
item.description: One of BBC Breakfast's main presenters, Louise Minchin, has broadcast her final programme after 20 years of early morning alarm calls.

item.title: Gleision: 'Guilt of surviving mine disaster with me forever'
item.description: A decade on from the Gleision mine disaster, two men who survived still carry the weight of the tragedy.

item.title: Pennies back in production as cash is hoarded during Covid
item.description: No new 1p coins were made by the Royal Mint in 2018 and 2019 but production resumed last year.

item.title: Claims about Universal Credit fact-checked
item.description: The government and Labour traded claims about the decision to remove the £20 extra Universal Credit payment.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: How Rose Ayling-Ellis will hear the music
item.description: EastEnders star Rose Ayling-Ellis will become the show's first deaf contestant later this month.

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'You can run a business and have a baby'
item.description: Planning for a maternity leave when you're the boss of a fast-growing company.

item.title: ‘Improving my literacy helped me get a different job’
item.description: New research found that low levels of literacy costs workers an extra 18 months in lost earnings.

item.title: Miss Ireland 2021: First black winner 'proud' of crown
item.description: Pamela Uba moved to the country as a seven-year-old - now she's making history after taking the title.

item.title: Manchester City 6-3 RB Leipzig: Last season's runners-up off to flying start
item.description: Jack Grealish scores a wonderful goal on his Champions League debut as Manchester City put the pain of losing last season's final behind them to beat RB Leipzig.

item.title: Athletics coach Salazar fails in appeal against four-year doping ban
item.description: Banned athletics coach Alberto Salazar's four-year suspension is upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas).

item.title: Murray out of Rennes Open at last-16 stage
item.description: Andy Murray loses 6-2 4-6 6-1 to Russia's Roman Safiullin in last 16 at the Rennes Open

item.title: Warwickshire beat Yorkshire to stay in County Championship title hunt
item.description: Warwickshire beat Yorkshire to keep their County Championship title ambitions alive and end their opponents' hopes.

item.title: Messi kept quiet on full debut as PSG draw at Bruges
item.description: Lionel Messi struggles to make an impact on his first start for Paris St-Germain as they are held to a draw at Club Bruges.

item.title: NFL This Week: Jason Bell and Osi Umenyiora discuss Patrick Mahomes and Baker Mayfield
item.description: NFL This Week's Jason Bell and Osi Umenyiora discuss the differences between quarterbacks Patrick Mahomes and Baker Mayfield after Mahomes guided the Kansas City Chiefs to victory over Mayfield's Cleveland Browns.

item.title: Women's Super League: Ella Toone's long-range stunner for Man Utd features in best goals
item.description: Watch the best goals from the latest round of Women's Super League action, including Ella Toone's long-range stunner for Manchester United.

item.title: Is it safe to vaccinate our child? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about vaccinating 12-15 year-olds, the booster vaccine and other topics.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: People in England could be told to work from home once again through the autumn and winter.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: People are vaccinated - so why are there so many cases?
item.description: More than four out of five UK adults are now fully vaccinated, but daily case rates remain high.

item.title: Job vacancies: How do I find a new job and who is hiring?
item.description: There are record numbers of empty positions, figures show, so which sectors are looking to recruit?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Face coverings could become a legal requirement in England again if the NHS struggles this winter.

item.title: What difference will jabbing young teens make?
item.description: How to weigh the pros and cons of a vaccine for a disease that is rarely serious in young people.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: All children aged 12-15 across the UK will be offered one dose of the Pifzer vaccine.

item.title: Covid: Which countries are vaccinating children and why?
item.description: Millions of children around the world are being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Flu jab 2021: Who’s eligible for a free vaccine?
item.description: This year's roll out has expanded in an attempt to shield against a double whammy of flu and Covid.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid: Will I need a jab and what will university be like this term?
item.description: Many Covid restrictions have been lifted for students going to university this term.

item.title: 'The near-death experience that made me a top musician'
item.description: When Tony Kofi had a near-fatal accident, he had a vision of himself playing a musical instrument. It would change his life forever.

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.

item.title: 'I studied law in jail - now I want to change the system'
item.description: LaTonya Myers spent nine months in jail because she couldn’t afford bail - now she's helping others facing the same challenge.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.
